title: How can evolution be proven with empirical evidence? - Quora

response.answer_text: Good grief. It’s 2017, not 1917, not 1817. Evolution was empircally demonstrated to the complete satisfaction of the scientific community before your grandparents were born. I don’t know what cultural backwater bubble you were raised in, but you need to deal with reality if you want to have a meaningful existence. Evolution is settled science, not to mean that research isn’t refining our understanding of it every day, but the backbone is there, proven by consilience. Consilience is the way in which a multitude of avenues of research, using a variety of tools and datasets and reasoning, all converging on a common conclusion. Thus, for example, plate tectonics, from geology, “proves” evolution. DNA sequencing and analyses “proves” evolution. The fossil record “proves” evolution. The fact of many organisms evolving since science started studying living organisms “proves” evolution. Darwin’s observations in the Galapagos Islands “proved” evolution. There are literally thousands more examples. Evolution is as proven as internal combustion. You really need to devote your time to learning about evolution instead of pretending it’s 150 years ago when this was an actual topic.  Sorry about the typos. The first image is also incorrect in that it has been discovered that our ancestors walked fully upright going back over 6 million years. They were just smaller, with monkey heads on top of their human-ish bodies, roughly speaking. The bigger picture:  The “origin of life” part was one simple organism 1.6 billion years ago. Probably originating from a millions of years long process around a hydrothermal event, perhaps one found (now inactive) in a western Australian desert north of Perth.

Endogenous retroviruses or ERVs Common ancestry was proved when it was discovered that both humans and chimps have identical sets of damaged DNA in identical locations caused by extremely rare chance encounters with viruses who accidentally integrated themselves into a sperm or egg cell of an ancestral primate and became a hereditary marker across all evolutionary species. These endogenized retroviruses (ERV) not only proved our ancestry with chimps, but are revealing our connection to other more distant cousins like the gorillas, gibbons and lemurs. ERV #HERV-K10 is one such example. HERV-K10 is present in all primates and humans except for the New World Monkeys (the really small mouse-like monkeys like the tamarin and marmoset). This means that HERV-K10 virus was embedded after we all split from the New World Monkey lineage but before we split from the main primate tree. ERV #SINE-R and ZNF80 are two other embedded virus that are only found in humans, chimps and gorillas. This means that SINE-R and ZNF80 was embedded after we all split from the orangutans, gibbons and lemurs but before we split from the chimps and gorillas. ERV #SINE-RC2 is only found in humans. This means that SINE-RC2 was embedded after we split from the chimps and gorillas. There have been more than 40 of these identical ERVs identified in the human/chimp species alone and further mapping studies indicates that there may be in excess of 100,000 ERVs across all vertebrates making a detailed history of all evolutionary relationships possible. Work is underway to identify all of the ERVs in the entire primate family. Proof of the endogenization process caan be currently seen in real time through the koala lineage who have recently become infected with a gammaretrovirus called KoRV. ERVs are as smoking as the gun that puts criminals in jail for murder. Where a court of law only needs one match to convict a person, ERV's provide more than 40 matches for common ancestry. It would be deniable if you could show identical chimp/human ERVs in a rabbit, whale or a cat ..... but you can't. ERVs are viruses that infected a common ancestor - not junk DNA that just so happened to look like each other in 43 different places on our genomes. Some creationists have buckled under the evidence and now claim that the viruses attack hotspots - of course these hotspots just happen to be where human / chimp insertion sites match. But the study of HIV shows this is false and that the insertions are highly random - attacking anywhere along 240 million different sites - perhaps even more. But that's not all there is to this story. Genetic drifting - the slow mutilation of DNA segments over time - also affects ERVs and identically mutilated ERVs have been found in humans and chimps. Lastly, the identically mutilated ERVs have also identically deteriorated over time indicating the same date of integration in humans and chimps. Do you believe children are identical with their parents? No; nobody does. No one denies there is variation in what is inherited in offspring. Do you believe that a bunny rabbit that can’t run very fast has the same chance of surviving to produce offspring as his faster siblings? No; obviously not. Congratulations! you believe in Natural Selection. That’s all there is to it. Nothing to prove: it’s nothing beyond these 2 facts: 1. Inheritable variation exists within populations (even nominal clones). 2. Variations better adapted to their environment will on average live longer to produce more offspring than those less well adapted. The second point is more a tautology than an assertion of fact. It might be argued that we have been interfering with that process for the last few thousand years to create domesticated animals like chickens, cattle, and innumerable breeds of dogs; and new foods like corn and grapefruit, etc., so it’s not Natural any more: Artificial Selection! But aren’t we part of Nature? We have indeed sped the selection process up drastically, and it’s not clear whether Nature’s latest experiment with brains that tinker with Selection itself will turn out well for us (Nature, of course, remains indifferent). I think the still widespread feeling that there’s something here that needs proving stems from widespread adoption of the entirely misleading and contentious term Evolution over the straightforward and self-explanatory Natural Selection. I read that Darwin regretted his single use of the E word; using everywhere else the benign Natural Selection. Contention might fade away if we stop using that E word!

If you read the definition, it is simply a description of natural processes of mutation and natural selection. It is not a theory, and certainly not The Theory of Evolution, (TOE). The TOE is quite different as it makes claims about evolution that contradict science and the definition. Note that I said the definition is observable and demonstrable. The TOE is neither and never has been. Note this - “All life on Earth shares a last universal common ancestor (LUCA) that lived approximately 3.5–3.8 billion years ago.” This is the foundation of the TOE and requires that the Phylogenetic Tree on which it is based, is true. It isn’t. It is pure speculation and unsupported assumption. Here it is… Google Image Result for https://globalchange.umich.edu/fossil1.jpg Just one example of how evolutionists express their “proof” or “evidence” of their claims. Often referred to by evolutionists, but never actually read by them, it appears. Right at the start, is how they analyse things. Bold mine. Phylogenetic tree - Wikipedia “A speculatively rooted tree for rRNA genes, showing the three life domains: bacteria, archaea, and eukaryota. The black branch at the bottom of the phylogenetic tree connects the three branches of living organisms to the last universal common ancestor. A rooted phylogenetic tree, each node with descendants represents the inferred most recent common ancestor of those descendants, and the edge lengths in some trees may be interpreted as time estimates. Each node is called a taxonomic unit. Internal nodes are generally called hypothetical taxonomic units, as they cannot be directly observed. Trees are useful in fields of biology such as bioinformatics, systematics, and phylogenetics. Unrooted trees illustrate only the relatedness of the leaf nodes and do not require the ancestral root to be known or inferred. Although phylogenetic trees produced on the basis of sequenced genes or genomic data in different species can provide evolutionary insight, these analyses have important limitations. Most importantly, the trees that they generate are not necessarily correct – they do not necessarily accurately represent the evolutionary history of the included taxa. As with any scientific result, they are subject to falsification by further study (e.g., gathering of additional data, analyzing the existing data with improved methods). The data on which they are based may be noisy; the analysis can be confounded by genetic recombination, horizontal gene transfer, hybridisation between species that were not nearest neighbors on the tree before hybridisation takes place, convergent evolution, and conserved sequences. Phylogenetic trees can also be inferred from a range of other data types, including morphology, the presence or absence of particular types of genes, insertion and deletion events – and any other observation thought to contain an evolutionary signal.” So the tree, is pure speculation. LUCA? Pure speculation. Unidentified, unidentifiable, indescribable, it is a myth, a figment of the imagination. So with every single one of all so-called “common ancestors”, all missing from every branch of this mythical tree.

You don’t “prove” evolution, you observe it, like you observe other things. Can you “prove hurricanes”, or “prove apples”? It’s a really weird thing to say. It’s a different thing to propose an explanation for how it works, and that’s the theory of evolution. Still, you cannot “prove” it, you can test and confirm its predictions, and fail to disprove it. If it has predictive power, then it is useful, so we use it. And that’s why we use the theory of evolution to explain how evolution works. If you’re asking how to confirm the theory of evolution, the then answer is that you test its predictions, as with any other theory. The theory of evolution explains that evolution is driven by natural selection, that the change in alleles frequencies in a population over time will tend towards better adaptation to the population’s environment, due to natural selection. Those individuals who are more fit to their environemnt will tend to statistically survive and reproduce more successfully than those who are not, which means that the alleles that produce better fitness will become more common in the population over time, and therefore the population as a whole will become more fit to its environment. So that’s what you test. It’s been demonstrates so, so many times. And this simpe fact is used in many different fields, and is behind a lot of modern technology, not just in biology, but also in fields related to computer science, as not only living things can evolve things way. We also evovle designs, and use evolution by natural seleciton in machine learning and advanced robots, for example. But honestly, you shouldn’t even have to demonstrate this empirically, since it’s so obvious through logic that natural selection will produce evolution towards better fitness.

OK, learn a bit about the scientific method. Scientific theories are never proved - only DISproved. Empirical evidence may support theories, be inconclusive, or contradict them - in the latter case, disproving them.
Evolution HAS been proven with empirical evidence, many times. Google it.
Look at the fossil record.  Find a species that reproduces quickly, control it’s environment, and watch how it evolves over time to thrive in that environment.
Proof is not something you do with a scientific theory. You CONFIRM it. The biological theory of evolution has been confirmed again and again and again since its introduction in 1859.
That evolution occurs in living populations has been proven by direct observation in real time (how else did you think antibiotic resistant strains of bacteria like MRSA arose?)
You cannot prove anything with empirical evidence. Read Belief, Proof and Science.
